questions.question: Which of the following is NOT an essential element of a valid contract?

options.B: Acceptance

questions.explanation: The essential elements of a valid contract are: (1) offer, (2) acceptance, (3) consideration, and (4) legal capacity of parties and legality of purpose. Writing is not required for all contracts, though some must be in writing under the Statute of Frauds.
questions.tip: Contract elements: Offer + Acceptance + Consideration + Capacity/Legality. Writing only for certain contracts.

questions.question: A valid offer must be:

options.B: Definite and certain in its terms

questions.explanation: A valid offer must be: (1) definite and certain in its terms, (2) communicated to the offeree, and (3) made with serious intent. Vague proposals or invitations to negotiate are not offers.
questions.tip: Offer = definite terms + communicated + serious intent. Ads usually aren't offers (invitations to deal).

questions.question: Consideration in a contract is best defined as:

options.A: The written terms of the agreement
options.B: Something of legal value exchanged by the parties

questions.explanation: Consideration is something of legal value (benefit or detriment) exchanged by the parties. It represents the bargained-for exchange that makes the contract binding. Past consideration and gifts are generally not valid consideration.
questions.tip: Consideration = bargained-for exchange. Both parties must give something of value.

questions.question: A bilateral contract is formed when:

options.A: One party makes a promise in exchange for the other party's performance
options.B: Both parties exchange promises
options.D: The contract is for goods over $500

questions.explanation: A bilateral contract involves an exchange of promises—both parties promise to do something. A unilateral contract involves a promise in exchange for performance (completed action). Most contracts are bilateral.
questions.tip: Bilateral = promise for promise. Unilateral = promise for performance. Most contracts are bilateral.

questions.question: Under the Statute of Frauds, which contract must generally be in writing to be enforceable?

options.B: A contract for services to be completed in one week
options.C: A contract for the sale of goods priced at $500 or more
options.D: A contract for painting a house

questions.explanation: The Statute of Frauds requires certain contracts to be in writing, including: sale of goods $500+ (UCC), real property interests, contracts not performable within one year, promises to pay another's debt, and marriage-related promises.
questions.tip: MY LEGS: Marriage, Year+, Land, Executor, Goods $500+, Surety. These need writing.

questions.question: Under common law, an acceptance that changes the terms of the offer is:

options.B: A counteroffer that rejects the original offer
options.D: Valid if the change is minor

questions.explanation: Under the common law mirror image rule, an acceptance must be unconditional and match the offer exactly. Any variation in terms constitutes a counteroffer, which rejects the original offer. The UCC has different rules for merchants.
questions.tip: Mirror image rule (common law): Acceptance must match offer exactly. Any change = counteroffer.

questions.question: A contract entered into by a minor is generally:

options.B: Voidable at the option of the minor
options.C: Voidable at the option of the adult party

questions.explanation: Contracts with minors are voidable at the minor's option. The minor can choose to disaffirm (cancel) the contract or ratify it upon reaching majority. The adult party is bound and cannot void the contract.
questions.tip: Minor's contracts = voidable by minor. Minor chooses to enforce or disaffirm. Adult is bound.

questions.question: A contract entered into under duress is:

options.B: Voidable by the party under duress

questions.explanation: A contract made under duress (threats of harm or illegal pressure) is voidable by the victim. Physical duress may make a contract void, while economic duress makes it voidable. The victim can choose to enforce or rescind.
questions.tip: Duress = voidable by victim. Physical duress may be void. Victim chooses whether to enforce.

questions.question: A mutual mistake about a material fact in a contract allows:

options.A: Either party to rescind the contract
options.B: Only the party at fault to rescind

questions.explanation: A mutual (bilateral) mistake about a material fact makes the contract voidable by either party. The mistake must be about a basic assumption that materially affects the exchange. Unilateral mistakes generally don't allow rescission unless the other party knew.
questions.tip: Mutual mistake = either party can rescind. Unilateral mistake = generally stuck with contract.

questions.question: Contract rights generally can be assigned unless:

options.B: The assignment is prohibited by law or the contract, or materially changes the obligor's duties

questions.explanation: Contract rights are generally assignable, but exceptions include: (1) assignment prohibited by statute, (2) contract terms prohibit assignment, (3) assignment materially changes obligor's duties/risks, or (4) personal service contracts.
questions.tip: Most rights assignable. Exceptions: prohibited, personal services, materially changes duties.

questions.question: An intended third party beneficiary can enforce a contract:

options.A: Only after both original parties agree
options.B: Once their rights have vested

questions.explanation: An intended third party beneficiary can enforce a contract once their rights vest. Rights vest when: (1) the beneficiary manifests assent, (2) brings suit, or (3) materially changes position in reliance. Incidental beneficiaries cannot enforce.
questions.tip: Intended beneficiary = can enforce once vested. Incidental beneficiary = no rights.

questions.question: Under the doctrine of substantial performance, a party who substantially performs:

options.B: Can recover the contract price minus damages for defects
options.C: Is in total breach of contract
options.D: Must perform again from the beginning

questions.explanation: Substantial performance means the party has performed most obligations in good faith, with only minor deviations. The performing party can recover the contract price, but the non-breaching party can deduct damages for defects.
questions.tip: Substantial performance = can recover contract price minus cost to fix defects. Doesn't apply to UCC sales.

questions.question: Anticipatory breach occurs when:

options.B: A party clearly indicates they will not perform before performance is due

questions.explanation: Anticipatory breach (repudiation) occurs when a party unequivocally indicates, before performance is due, that they will not perform. The non-breaching party can: (1) treat the contract as breached immediately and sue, (2) wait and see, or (3) urge performance.
questions.tip: Anticipatory breach = clear statement of non-performance before due date. Can sue immediately.

questions.question: Compensatory damages for breach of contract are designed to:

options.B: Put the non-breaching party in the position they would have been in if the contract was performed
options.C: Return parties to their pre-contract positions
options.D: Provide a bonus to the non-breaching party

questions.explanation: Compensatory damages aim to give the non-breaching party the benefit of their bargain—putting them in the position they would have been in had the contract been performed. This is the expectation interest.
questions.tip: Compensatory = benefit of the bargain (expectation). Punitive damages rare in contracts.

questions.question: Specific performance is most likely to be granted for breach of a contract involving:

options.B: Fungible goods

questions.explanation: Specific performance (court-ordered completion of contract) is granted when money damages are inadequate, typically for unique items. Real property is always considered unique. Personal service contracts won't be specifically enforced (involuntary servitude concerns).
questions.tip: Specific performance for unique items (land, art). Never for personal services.

questions.question: A contract may be discharged by impossibility when:

options.A: Performance becomes more expensive than expected
options.B: The subject matter is destroyed through no fault of either party
options.C: One party decides they don't want to perform

questions.explanation: True impossibility discharges contract obligations when performance becomes objectively impossible through no fault of either party (e.g., subject matter destroyed, death of person essential to contract, law makes performance illegal). Mere difficulty or expense increase is not impossibility.
questions.tip: Impossibility = objectively impossible (not just harder). Subject destroyed, essential person dies, illegality.

questions.question: UCC Article 2 governs contracts for:

options.B: Sale of goods

questions.explanation: UCC Article 2 applies to contracts for the sale of goods (movable, tangible personal property). Services, real estate, and securities are governed by common law. Mixed contracts use the predominant purpose test.
questions.tip: UCC Article 2 = goods only. Services, real estate, employment = common law.

questions.question: Under UCC Article 2, a merchant's firm offer:

options.B: Is irrevocable without consideration for up to 3 months if in writing
options.C: Can be revoked at any time

questions.explanation: Under UCC Section 2-205, a merchant's written offer to buy or sell goods that states it will be held open is irrevocable for the stated time (or reasonable time if none stated), up to 3 months, without consideration. Common law requires consideration for option contracts.
questions.tip: UCC firm offer: Merchant + written + states open = irrevocable up to 3 months. No consideration needed.

questions.question: Under the parol evidence rule, prior or contemporaneous oral evidence may be admitted to:

options.B: Add additional terms to a complete integration
options.C: Explain ambiguous terms or show fraud, mistake, or illegality

questions.explanation: The parol evidence rule bars prior/contemporaneous evidence that contradicts a written contract intended as final. Exceptions: evidence to explain ambiguity, show fraud/duress/mistake/illegality, prove conditions precedent, or show lack of consideration.
questions.tip: Parol evidence rule: Can't contradict writing. CAN explain ambiguity, show fraud/mistake/illegality.

questions.question: Liquidated damages clauses are enforceable if:

options.A: The amount is significantly higher than actual damages
options.B: Actual damages are difficult to estimate and the amount is reasonable
options.D: The contract is for goods over $500

questions.explanation: Liquidated damages are enforceable if: (1) actual damages are difficult to estimate at contract formation, and (2) the amount is a reasonable forecast of damages. If the amount is a penalty (punitive), it will not be enforced.
questions.tip: Liquidated damages: Must be reasonable estimate when damages hard to measure. Penalties void.

questions.question: An accord and satisfaction requires:

options.B: A new agreement (accord) and performance of that agreement (satisfaction)
options.D: Payment of the original amount due

questions.explanation: Accord and satisfaction discharges contract obligations through: (1) accord—a new agreement to accept different performance, and (2) satisfaction—actual performance of the accord. Until satisfaction, the original duty remains.
questions.tip: Accord = new agreement. Satisfaction = performing the accord. Both needed to discharge.

questions.question: Under UCC Article 2, a contract modification:

options.B: Does not require consideration if made in good faith

questions.explanation: Under UCC 2-209, modifications to contracts for goods do not require consideration if made in good faith. Common law requires consideration for modifications (the pre-existing duty rule). This is a significant UCC difference.
questions.tip: UCC modifications: No consideration needed, just good faith. Common law: Need new consideration.

questions.question: Under UCC 2-207, between merchants, additional terms in an acceptance:

options.A: Always become part of the contract
options.B: Never become part of the contract
options.C: Become part of the contract unless they materially alter it, the offer limits acceptance, or objection is made

questions.explanation: UCC 2-207 abandons the mirror image rule. Between merchants, additional terms in acceptance become part of the contract UNLESS: (1) offer expressly limits acceptance, (2) terms materially alter the contract, or (3) timely objection is made.
questions.tip: UCC 2-207 (merchants): Additional terms in unless material, limited by offer, or objected to.

questions.question: The UCC statute of limitations for breach of a sales contract is:

options.B: 4 years

questions.explanation: Under UCC 2-725, the statute of limitations for breach of a sales contract is 4 years from the date the breach occurs (usually delivery). Parties can agree to reduce this to as short as 1 year, but cannot extend it.
questions.tip: UCC SOL = 4 years from breach. Can reduce to 1 year by agreement. Cannot extend.

questions.question: The implied warranty of merchantability:

options.B: Applies only when the seller is a merchant of that type of goods
options.D: Requires the goods to be perfect

questions.explanation: The implied warranty of merchantability arises only when the seller is a merchant dealing in goods of that kind. It warrants that goods are fit for ordinary purposes, adequately packaged, conform to labels, and are of fair average quality.
questions.tip: Merchantability: Seller must be merchant of those goods. Goods fit for ordinary purpose.

questions.question: To disclaim the implied warranty of merchantability under the UCC, the disclaimer must:

options.A: Be in writing and conspicuous, mentioning 'merchantability'
options.B: Be in any form

questions.explanation: To disclaim the implied warranty of merchantability, the disclaimer must: (1) mention the word 'merchantability,' and (2) if written, be conspicuous. Alternatively, 'as is' or similar language disclaims all implied warranties without mentioning merchantability specifically.
questions.tip: Disclaim merchantability: Use 'merchantability' + conspicuous, OR use 'as is.'

questions.question: In a contract stating 'FOB shipping point,' risk of loss passes to the buyer when:

options.B: Goods are delivered to the carrier at the shipping point

questions.explanation: FOB (Free on Board) shipping point means risk of loss passes to the buyer when goods are delivered to the carrier at the seller's location. The buyer bears the risk during transit. FOB destination means seller bears risk until delivery.
questions.tip: FOB shipping point = risk on buyer during transit. FOB destination = seller's risk until arrival.

questions.question: When a seller breaches by delivering nonconforming goods, the buyer may:

options.A: Only accept all goods or reject all goods
options.B: Accept all, reject all, or accept conforming units and reject nonconforming units

questions.explanation: Under UCC 2-601 (perfect tender rule), if goods fail to conform in any respect, the buyer may: (1) reject all, (2) accept all, or (3) accept conforming commercial units and reject the rest. Rejection must be timely with notice to seller.
questions.tip: Buyer's UCC options: Accept all, reject all, or accept some/reject some. Must give timely notice.

questions.question: When a buyer breaches by wrongfully rejecting goods, a seller may:

options.A: Only sue for the contract price
options.B: Withhold delivery, resell goods, recover difference, and/or recover incidental damages

questions.explanation: Upon buyer's breach, seller's remedies include: (1) withhold delivery, (2) stop goods in transit, (3) resell goods and recover difference, (4) recover damages (contract price minus market price plus incidentals), or (5) recover price if goods cannot be resold.
questions.tip: Seller's UCC remedies: Withhold, stop transit, resell, sue for damages/price, incidentals.

questions.question: Contract duties can generally be delegated unless:

options.B: The duties involve personal skill, trust, or the contract prohibits delegation

questions.explanation: Duties generally can be delegated, but exceptions include: (1) duties requiring personal skill or judgment, (2) duties involving special trust, (3) contract prohibits delegation, or (4) delegation would materially change the obligee's expectancy.
questions.tip: Delegation: Generally allowed. NOT for personal services or if prohibited. Delegator stays liable!

questions.question: Under ESIGN and UETA, electronic signatures are:

options.B: Valid only for small transactions
options.C: Generally given the same legal effect as handwritten signatures

questions.explanation: ESIGN (federal) and UETA (state) laws generally give electronic signatures and records the same legal effect as their paper equivalents. Exceptions exist for certain documents like wills, family law matters, and some UCC transactions.
questions.tip: E-signatures = valid like handwritten. ESIGN/UETA. Some exceptions (wills, family law).

questions.question: A court may refuse to enforce an unconscionable contract if:

options.B: The terms are grossly unfair and there was unequal bargaining power at formation
options.D: The price is below market value

questions.explanation: Unconscionability has two elements: (1) procedural—unfair surprise or unequal bargaining power, and (2) substantive—grossly unfair terms. Courts can refuse enforcement, limit application, or strike offending clauses. It's determined at time of formation.
questions.tip: Unconscionability: Procedural (unfair process) + Substantive (unfair terms). Court decides.

questions.question: A seller's right to cure nonconforming goods under the UCC exists when:

options.B: Time for performance has not yet expired, or seller reasonably believed goods would be acceptable

questions.explanation: UCC 2-508 allows sellers to cure by: (1) notifying buyer and delivering conforming goods if time for performance hasn't expired, or (2) if seller reasonably believed goods would be acceptable (e.g., prior course of dealing), seller gets reasonable additional time to cure.
questions.tip: Seller can cure: If time remains OR reasonably believed goods OK. Must notify buyer.

questions.question: Frustration of purpose discharges a contract when:

options.B: An unforeseen event substantially destroys the principal purpose of the contract

questions.explanation: Frustration of purpose excuses performance when: (1) an event occurs whose nonoccurrence was a basic assumption, (2) the event substantially frustrates the principal purpose, and (3) the party isn't at fault. Different from impossibility—performance is possible but pointless.
questions.tip: Frustration: Performance possible but purpose destroyed. Classic case: coronation postponed.

questions.question: The duty to mitigate damages requires the non-breaching party to:

options.B: Take reasonable steps to minimize losses after breach

questions.explanation: The non-breaching party has a duty to take reasonable steps to minimize damages. Failure to mitigate reduces recoverable damages by the amount that could have been avoided. The party need not take extraordinary or unreasonable measures.
questions.tip: Must mitigate: Take reasonable steps to reduce loss. Can't recover avoidable damages.
